The date when the theft occurred, as per the official report: the robbery took place on Sunday, October 20, 2025, at 9:34 a.m., with the robbers leaving at 9:38 a.m.

The time when the robbers entered the Apollo Gallery, suggesting the heist was executed during the museum’s opening hours, maximizing the element of surprise and access.

keyTakeAways: A high-value heist occurred at the Louvre Museum in Paris, where approximately 88 million euros ($102 million) worth of royal jewelry was stolen, including a tiara and necklace with historical significance from the Napoleonic era.
The thieves used a truck-mounted ladder to break into the Apollo Gallery through a window, equipped with tools such as an angle grinder and blowtorch, and fled using two scooters along the Seine.
Eight of the nine stolen items remain unaccounted for, and experts believe the jewelry has likely been dismantled and sold on the black market or melted down for financial gain.

French Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin admitted that security failures—such as unsecured windows and a basket lift on a public road—exposed critical vulnerabilities in the museum’s protection systems.
The heist has sparked national concern in France, with public sentiment viewing it as a deep historical and cultural attack, as noted by author Elaine Sciolino.
Investigators have recovered one of the two scooters and a helmet, and are conducting a fume-treatment of the truck to recover DNA and fingerprints, though progress is slow.
Experts, including Christopher Marinello of Art Recovery International, warn that the thieves may have broken the jewelry down to sell the metals or recut stones, making recovery nearly impossible.
The case is seen as potentially linked to organized crime, with concerns that the loot was used for money laundering.
This heist echoes past museum robberies such as the 1911 theft of the Mona Lisa and the 1998 theft of a Camille Corot painting, and is part of a broader pattern of art theft in Europe.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A high-profile heist at the Louvre Museum in Paris, occurring on Sunday, October 20, 2025, saw approximately $102 million worth of royal jewelry—belonging to queens Marie-Amélie and Hortense and a gift from Napoleon to Marie-Louise—stolen by two armed men who used a truck-mounted ladder and tools such as an angle grinder and blowtorch to break into the Apollo Gallery. The heist lasted just four minutes, with the robbers leaving at 9:38 a.m. and fleeing on scooters along the Seine. Despite ongoing investigations, including the recovery of a scooter and helmet, and efforts to extract DNA from the truck, experts believe the jewelry has likely been dismantled or melted to facilitate money laundering. Security failures, including unsecured windows and public access to a basket lift, have been publicly acknowledged by French officials. Experts and public figures, including Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin and author Elaine Sciolino, emphasize the deep cultural and national trauma of the theft, comparing it to past museum heists like the 1911 Mona Lisa robbery. There is widespread concern that the items are permanently lost, and the case is suspected to be linked to organized crime.
